text.body:
FPO COPY The main eCommerce website for Tommy Bahama was being moved to a new platform and at the same time, it was getting a aesthetic refresh.

I was tasked at picking up this project that had been partially completed. While the previous owner of the project had done quite a bit of work, I had the disadvantage of not having a lot of background before being thrown into this project.. A lot of the styling was inconsistent and I had to go through and make sure that consistency was put in place, so that future revisions could be made easier.

Another added obstacle in the site revision, was that, there were few layout changes that could be made in the amount of time allotted. Aesthetic changes needed to be carefully considered, while maintaining business needs. The ask was for the site to have a lighter, more modern aesthetic, while allowing the product to shine. Simplicity was the approach that I took, in order to let the product speak for itself. Some minor navigation changes helped declutter the home page, while button colors were consolidated to reflect a more cohesive and consistent visual language.

FPO COPY After the main site had been cleaned up, the mobile site needed some much needed attention. I was restricted to using the same layout and technology platform that was currently being used. But by updating colors, fonts, and icons, I was able to make the mobile site feel more inline with the new look and feel of the main site.

FPO COPY Tommy Bahama sends out over 400 emails a year, and that isnâ€™t including the geo-targeted ones. I have done my fair share of them.

They range from simple templated emails to quick-turn custom messaging that was due yesterday, even though you received the brief an hour ago.

FPO COPY The fun and quirky neighborhood of Fremont in Seattle was in need of a digital portal where the art director and artists could connect for the monthly artwalk. It also needed to be a place where attendees could find information quickly.

I used illustrations of the neighborhood icons and bright colors to capture the eccentricity of the neighborhood, while utilizing a straightforward and easy to navigate layout to make it easy for both participants and attendees to get the information that they need.

I used illustrations of the neighborhood icons and bright colors to capture the eccentricity of the neighborhood, while utilizing a straightforward and easy to navigate layout to make it easy for both participants and attendees to get the information that they need.

FPO COPY While working in house for the Zumiez private label team, I got the opportunity to work on a number of different apparel brands. Each brand targeted a different segment of a similar demographic. The brands, which catered to 13-25 year old skateboarders and snowboarders, ran from technical to trendy, with a little bit of everything in between.

The samples seen here are just a few examples of apparel packaging that I designed while I was there. Most packaging groups usually contained well over 50+ items per group, with 3-4 packaging groups being developed at one time. I concepted, designed, created production files, tracked, worked with domestic and overseas vendors, to produce samples and made all final approvals that came through.

FPO COPY In my free time, I freelance and volunteer with a number of promoters and organizations to create event promotions. These are a number of posters that I created for a few groups. Most of the posters usually had an accompanying flyer. Sometimes I would be asked to create additional collateral including lapel pins, merch and social media assets.

FPO COPY T-shirts were a staple business at Zumiez when I was working there. 5-10 tees would be designed on a monthly basis, all of which had to be on trend, timely, and desirable.

On top of designing, I also created all of the technical packages that accompanies most apparel design, which includes all the measurements and details the end product should have.

I worked directly with domestic and overseas vendors to get the artwork I designed, produced.

There were also times when I was asked to art direct third party vendors, whom I would provide trend analysis,

FPO COPY Working on the private label team at Zumiez allowed me to develop some a lot of new skills. One of the skills that I learned was all over fabric printing. My patterns adorned everything from apparel to backpacks, wallets, belts, the list goes on. I was able to utilize various types of techniques including sublimation, discharge printing, silk-screen, as well as large scale engineered prints.

FPO COPY During my last year or so at Zumiez, the private label team was asked to design and produce price-point conscience private label longboard line.

I worked with buying team to come up with the the board shapes and construction. Once we finalized the technical aspects with the manufacturer, we customized wheels and trucks as well as worked on creating various designs to go on the bottom sides of the boards.

FPO COPY Zumiez has been producing private label boards for a number of years and I got the opportunity to design the graphics on a number of them while I worked there. Alibi is the first brand that I got to work on. Aperture was introduced later as a more technical brand.
